page.title: 18LANGUAGE AND DIALECT
page.content: Very little real dialect is still used in Ayton, except "thoo", meaning "thou or you", is still used by some older residents. A general tendency to use a short "a" as in "cat" for such words as "grass", and a long "u" as in "took" for such words as "cut" is common throughout the north. Local place names have been devised, such as "Cooks" for Easy Moor to the east of the area. Final consonants tend to vanish, so "Tunstall" becomes "Tunst'l". Great Ayton is known locally as "Canny Yatton", meaning big or fine Ayton. "Yat" is Scandanavian, meaning "gate" or "pass", as through a range of hills. "Langbaurgh" is a Saxon word meaning "long barrow" as mistakenly given to the basalt ridge to the north of the village.
